metadata.case_name: Kamlaprasad Khetan and Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills Ltd. is a public limited company where four branches of Khetan family held large number of shares, managed by a firm of Managing Agents constituted by four Khetan family members including Kedar Nath Khetan and Onkarmal Khetan (father of petitioner No.1).
Trouble arose in 1950-51 when Onkarmal Khetan withdrew large sums from accounts, leading to suits against him; he retaliated with suits for receiver and restraining general meetings.

Balance sheet for 1950-51 published June 1952 revealed Directors including authorised Controller utilised company funds for personal gain and breached Companies Act, leading to Suit No.4/1952 by petitioners for injunction against Directors.
Ex-parte injunction on July 8, 1952 vacated; fresh injunction June 3, 1953 confirmed by Allahabad High Court September 14, 1953.
Shareholders held extraordinary general meeting November 9, 1953 re-electing authorised Controller and others as Directors subject to court decision in Suit No.4/1952.
Suit No.4/1952 still pending as of July 31, 1956; petitioner No.1 obtained ex-parte adjournment.
Ministry of Food communication November 8, 1952 warned of investigation and takeover if mills unable to work due to disputes.
Order under s.3(4) Essential Supplies Act December 18, 1952 gave authorised Controller certain control functions over Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills.
Onkarmal filed writ petition against December 18, 1952 order; dismissed May 14, 1954 as infructuous.
Investigation under s.15 IDRA July 30, 1953; order under s.18A November 14, 1953 appointing authorised Controller for one year.
All s.18A appointments cancelled May 21, 1954 vesting management back in owner.
Fresh order under Essential Supplies Act July 16, 1954 giving control functions to authorised Controller.
Second s.15 investigation September 19, 1954 recommended takeover for three years.
Petitioners filed writ petition January 31, 1955 against July 16, 1954 order, amended against subsequent orders.
Order under s.18A November 8, 1955 (cancelling July 16, 1954 order) authorising Kedar Nath Khetan as authorised Controller for one year.
Amending order November 7, 1956 extending period to two years.
Mill earned profit in 1953-54 and likely Rs.84,321 in 1954-55.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated November 8, 1955 under s.18A IDRA fulfills essential requirements: investigation under s.15 and opinion of mismanagement highly detrimental to public interest.
Whether s.18A authorises extension of period via amending order dated November 7, 1956 complying with s.21 General Clauses Act.
Whether the orders are bona fide, given appointment of Kedar Nath Khetan who was party to dispute and subject to injunction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order November 8, 1955 invalid as Central Government could not rationally form opinion of mismanagement since authorised Controller was in charge from Dec 1952 to Nov 1955 with minor break.
Amending order November 7, 1956 invalid as s.18A does not authorise extension without fulfilling s.18A conditions again; does not comply with s.21 General Clauses Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.18A IDRA; s.21 General Clauses Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders not bona fide: appointed Kedar Nath Khetan, mismanaging party to dispute, against whom injunction passed, ceased to be Director due to Companies Act breaches.

respondent_arguments.text: Ongoing family disputes and litigation caused mismanagement detrimental to public interest; prior control orders insufficient, needed full takeover post s.15 investigation.
Amending order valid under s.21 General Clauses Act as exercised in like manner and conditions continued to exist.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.21 General Clauses Act; s.18A IDRA

respondent_arguments.text: Kedar Nath Khetan suitable due to experience; no ulterior purpose; petitioner No.1 not supported by majority shareholders.

court_reasoning.text: Essential requirements of s.18A(1)(b) fulfilled: s.15 investigation in Sept 1954, opinion of mismanagement valid due to ongoing disputes/litigation despite prior controls; distinction between control functions and full management takeover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conditions relate to period when management vested in owner; Central Govt had materials from disputes, second investigation recommending 3-year takeover.

court_reasoning.text: Amending order valid under s.21 General Clauses Act: exercised in like manner (notified); conditions (s.15 investigation, mismanagement by owner) continued as management not reverted to owner since Nov 8, 1955.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conditions not static or requiring re-fulfilment for amendment during takeover period; relate to pre-takeover by owner.

court_reasoning.text: Orders bona fide: selection of experienced Kedar Nath Khetan suitable despite being party to dispute; no evidence of ulterior purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test is absence of ulterior purpose beyond statutory object; Court cannot substitute propriety test.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. concurs except on amendment: s.21 conditions are those order subject to (e.g., max 5 years), not pre-conditions for power exercise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amendment complies as management not by owner at amendment time, but observes sub-s.(2) limit.

holdings.text: Orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 under s.18A IDRA valid; fulfill requirements; amendment valid under s.21 General Clauses Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Pronounced on Art.31(2) re Sholapur Ordinance/Act, led to cancellation of s.18A appointments May 21, 1954.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: s.21 General Clauses Act power of amendment cannot extend time retrospectively where functus officio; distinguished as here conditions/context of IDRA allow.

statutes_cited.name: Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for investigations, takeover orders, effects, cancellation; Chapter IIIA protected by Ninth Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to amend notified orders in like manner, subject to like conditions.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior control orders distinguished from full s.18A takeover.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition; s.18A validity not challenged due to Ninth Schedule protection.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 challenging validity of orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 appointing authorised Controller under s.18A IDRA dismissed; orders held valid, no violation of fundamental rights.
outcome.costs: Costs in favour of respondent Union of India; authorised Controller bears own costs.

key_quotes.text: the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on timing of s.18A conditions for original and amending orders.

key_quotes.text: The test to be applied is whether the appointment was made for some ulterior purpose, some purpose other than the object for which the law, under which the impugned order is made, was enacted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Standard for bona fides of appointment.
